Going to zero, based on GJP's response to my query re the technical raise that was reported by Associate Press. GJP's response follows: Thank you for your questions. GJ's question team is aware of OPEC's statements after the early December meeting and the media reporting of decisions made during that meeting. The question asked whether OPEC would announce a change in its production quota. We were very deliberate in how we worded the question and opted to focus on the quota, not the actual production levels because those are difficult to verify. We also opted to require an announcement by OPEC that there had been a change in the quota. They made no such announcement. In fact, they mentioned neither the quota nor production levels (http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/press_room/3193.htm). Most the reporting focused on OPEC inability to reach a decision on the quota and how they were maintaining current production (http://www.nyt imes.com/2015/12/05/business/energy-environment/opec-meeting-oil-production-price.html?_r=0 0, http://money.cnn.com/2015/12/04/investing/opec-meeting-oil-prices-saudi-arabia/, http://www.wsj.com/articles/oil-little-changed-as-investors-eye-opec-meeting-1449222485). I hope that explains our decision. We will continue to monitor the situation, but will close the question a "no" if there is no further news.

OPEC is not reacting yet, though the low crude oil prices are damaging the economies of all countries involved in this organization. The decision to keep up high production levels despite is dictated by political ambitions. In discussion are the goal of Saudi Arabia to weaken the US fracking industries, to weaken Russia, though it may be a side effect. Because USA imports less oil, Saudis are looking for alternative markets and trying to get a foot in to the EU market. The cheep oil from ISIS is pressing the prices as well. OPEC will have to react probably later in 2016 due to budgetary problems, but not fore January 1st 2016.
OPEC want to kill off fracking and alternative energy sources and so will continue to take the it of low prices in the hope of dominating the energy market in the future.

Opecs strategy seems to be "in place" at the moment. Recent meeting and no strategy change. Hard to see them change course within 15 days unless something like a breakout happens, which is deemed unlikely at this stage - more probable down the road as budgets come under greater pressure.

I share the following communication between myself and GJI . . .  Clarification request:  
There is significant controversy regarding wether or not OPEC has retained its quota/production ceiling or not. Please clarify!  From GJI this morning:
So sorry for the delay. After discussing the issues that you've raised, GJI's team has decided to retain the current resolution decision, which was to not close the OPEC question based on the news following the the November meeting. Please note that the question was about whether OPEC would ANNOUNCE changes to its production quota. It did not do that. We also don't consider the failure to reach a decision on the quota as evidence that the quota has changed.  We will continue to monitor the situation (looks like there is going to be an emergency meeting today) but will close the question as "no" if there is no further news.  I hope that helps explain our decision
~~~~~~~
COMMENTS:  As readers of my previous posts will know, I disagree with this interpretation of events.  Beyond that, I have two issues: 
1) today is December 15th, 11 days since the OPEC meeting.  You can bet I AM "sorry" for GJI's delay in responding to the controversy.
2) Reasonable people learn how to agree to disagree.  When it becomes necessary to accept that that is the situation, neither side trashes the other.  I continue to assert that GJI needs to create a mechanism whereby forecasters and GJI can agree to disagree without negatively impacting the forecaster's Brier score.

"after removing its production ceiling"
http://www.cnbc.com/2015/12/10/us-crude-oil-holds-near-2009-lows-as-global-glut-persists.html This question should be closed. The operative word is "any." Numerous changes were announced "to" the quota. There was a change in the method of promulgation (announcement) of the "quota" via communique (it was not mentioned), there was a change in that there was no re-confirmation of previously existing quotas (which were always previously re-confirmed), and, based upon the announcements of the Secretary-General and President, there was a change in that there was no agreement as to what the quota was, whereas in the previous period there was agreement. I could go on. There were numerous changes to the quota, the most prominent being structural and methodological. If the constituent elements of a complex signal are changed, has the complex signal changed? If the formula to create the exact same color of paint changes, has the paint changed? Of course it has.

I view much of what is being said outside official channels as noise and various sources maintain the static by reporting what happened in various ways. In searching for past precedents I found the following (Warning: sources continue to blast static): This is not the first time OPEC has failed to mention a production ceiling. At the 159th meeting in June 2011, OPEC members were unable to agree on production numbers for the first time in about 20 years. There doesn't even appear to be an official press release covering the conclusion of the 159th meeting. One major contributing factor in June 2011 was the uncertainty of Libyan production in light of the Arab Spring.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-opec-meeting-idUSKBN0TM30B20151205#LrQt9HRSZkr4I7AU.97 Articles from the time have a familiar ring to what we're seeing now, though the exact situation's are not identical. It's all a jumble of, "they maintained," or, "they deferred," or, "they couldn't agree" and so on, all set against the backdrop of their actual production estimated to have been 26.15 mb/d.
June 8, 2011 Headlines

They *did* modify the quota, in two ways. Firstly, they did a technical raise to 31.5 mbd, to accommodate the actual production (was previously 30 mbd). Secondly, they declared that they're going to do away with a specific quota announcement in the future. This question should probably be closed.

A cartel is only a cartel when it can act as a cartel.  What we are seeing here is cartel dissolution, possibly temporary, but dissolution nonetheless. Global oil production will overwhelm demand for another year or two.  Much of it comes from sources that are beyond OPEC control.  The essence of this question was whether desperate OPEC members like Venezuela could force a Saudi production cut to achieve a reduction in the OPEC production quota.  The Saudis will not budge (see my comment of Oct 23).  Since no other OPEC country is willing to cut production, the cartel now stands in ruins.  The argument and the essence of the question was never about whether to increase the OPEC production.  Given the current supply/demand context, that would be nonsensical.  Failure to maintain or reduce the production quota, is simply failure.  When a cartel cannot reach an effective agreement to limit production and control prices, it is no longer a functioning entity.  Sifting through the wreckage misses this reality.  OPEC no longer has the capacity to change any production quota.  That's just gone.

Let's contrast the statements in the minutes of the June meeting with the minutes of today's meeting: FROM THE MINUTES OF THE JUNE MEETING:  http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/press_room/3046.htm "In view of the foregoing, the Conference resolved to maintain the 30 mb/d ceiling and urged Member Countries to adhere to it.  Member Countries, in agreeing to this decision, confirmed their commitment to a stable and balanced oil market, with prices at levels that are suitable for both producers and consumers. Nonetheless, the Conference stressed that, given the current market uncertainties, the Secretariat should continue to closely monitor developments in the coming months.
~~~~~~~
FROM THE MINUTES OF TODAY'S MEETING:  http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/press_room/3193.htm ". . . . .emphasizing its commitment to ensuring a long-term stable and balanced oil market for both producers and consumers, the Conference agreed that Member Countries should continue to closely monitor developments in the coming months.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  In both sets of minutes there is a statement encouraging "closely monitoring of developments in the coming months".  HOWEVER, the minutes of the June meeting specifically state there was a resolution to maintain the 30mb/d ceiling while the minutes of today's meeting record that NO SUCH RESOLUTION WAS AGREED TO.  What was agreed at today's meeting was ONLY to continue to closely monitor developments in the coming months. The ceiling was not agreed to today.  It is gone.  Gone = change.

My thinking on this is as follows. They have this central issue that needs to be addressed in some way, at least symbolically:
• Current nominal group "production ceiling:" 30 million bpd*
• Actual group production (including Indonesia): 33 million bpd
• Symbolic imbalance: 3 million bpd (This is a credibility imbalance.) Thus, after much haggling, they will do with an increase in the production ceiling to approximately 31 million bpd, accompanied by a pledge (a kind-of, sort-of pledge) to adhere more strictly to the ceiling. (As discussed before, although there may not be "quotas" per se, there are, behind the scenes, informal "production targets" that members use to approach a country-by-country allocation of the ceiling [the "secret sauce.]) This is the only move they can make that will not throw the markets into panic one way or the other. Given the proper spin, it can even be presented as striving toward a 6% short-term "cut." They will announce an extraordinary meeting for early 2016 to address the increase from Iran of approximately 0.5 million bpd,, which they look forward to accommodating in an orderly fashion. (There is no need to address these new barrels right now since they are in the future anyway.) The extraordinary meeting will also have an eye toward monitoring the production discipline of all members, etc., etc. [I don't have a good enough understanding of middle-eastern culture, for if I did, with all due respect to Venezuela, et. al., I'd throw in some metaphor about getting the stubborn camel to get moving ...] * The 30 million bpd ceiling was first introduced, I believe, in 2009. Obviously the call of world demand from OPEC has increased since then. Even without Indonesia, the ceiling has fallen behind. [Edit: Here's another idea - "Saudi has chance to teach hedge funds a lesson"
http://blogs.reuters.com/breakingviews/2015/12/03/saudi-has-chance-to-teach-hedge-funds-a-lesson/ Either way, these two ideas offer a definte plan-of-action and a platform to build upon with the promise of group cohesion. Anything else, especially, a "do nothing" (but hope) approach, is only asking for market confusion and acrimony, and for the group to spin apart; not to even mention leaving money on the table.]

I've read many times that last fall Saudi Arabia "blocked" the desire of other members to cut production .  I have been wondering how this happened:  did KSA twist arms?  or was it incredibly persuasive?  is the vote by % of production?   does KSA have that many friends in OPEC?  So, I just did some research into voting at OPEC.   Voting is on the basis of one member, one vote.  HOWEVER, all votes impacting production must be unanimous.  So, any country not wanting to change the production quota can block something, even if everyone else wants it. I should have looked this up 2 months ago.   So, what kind of change would all agree to? Will Venezuela agree to an increase in the quota?  not unless it can be persuaded that doing so will improve the price.
Will KSA agree to a decrease in the quota?  I don't think so. I can't think of any change all would agree to.

Not that it makes much difference now - my average forecast is 12% -, but I'm going to the maximum till the OPEC meeting is over, just in case they do increase their overall quota because of the re-entrance of Indonesia.  Back in September, I was at 30-45% for a couple of weeks for this reason, but came down for the following reasons:-
1) It won't make a difference since the existing quota is being breached anyway.
2) They can't give Indonesia an individual quota without getting into the controversy of allocating quotas for everyone else.
3) Smaller members like Venezuela want a reduction and will oppose an increase, even if it makes no difference to actual supply. A unanimous decision is needed.
4)They could satisfy the members demanding a cut by sticking to the current ceiling even after Indonesia is included. This won't change the overall quota i.e. this question should resolve as "no" in such a case, but can be thought of as an overall cut by the amount that Indonesia produces (while OPEC as a whole continues to ignore the ceiling).

Think the technical aspect of this question is key: "..establishment or modification of country specific quotas will count.." The key here is Indonesia, rejoining after a 7 year hiatus, and adding some 900k bpd to output. That raises production for the 12+1 group to a little over 32mm bpd (31.38mm bpd last month ex Indonesia). So, even barring a technical adjustment of the 30mm bpd ceiling, it seems almost certain that there would be some minor modification of country specific quotas (especially considering that Iran may deviate some 400k between the lower & upper bounds of expected production). Add to this, the recent announcement of investments by Saudi Aramco to upgrade Indonesia's largest refinery (http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/26/saudi-aramco-indonesia-pertamina-idUSL3N13L42X20151126#uRy4UCM2tJgwEIxD.97) suggests to me that some modification of country specific quotas are in the cards.  In short, while I think a change to the overall quota is highly unlikely, this question seems to hinge on the 2nd section - a technical alteration that will count towards a "change" due to country specific adjustments.  Reference: http://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/MOMR_November_2015.pdf

COMMENTS:  
Since OPEC producers now only account for 40% of the world's production, any action by OPEC members may be compensated for by non-OPEC producers, blunting any impact on the price of oil.   This reality may preclude OPEC members from taking any action. However, when people are hurting, there is pressure to "do something".   Every member of OPEC would benefit from higher prices, but the members MOST eager to limit production or take other action in hopes of increasing the price of oil are the members LEAST likely to abide by any quota or rules imposed on them.  Establishing a price floor or quotas may sound appealing but without any enforcement, those producers willing to sell below that price floor or increase production will increase their market share and undermine the effort. Last year, Saudi Arabia's respected, veteran oil minister's arguments prevailed. This year, SA will not have such a powerful and respected person at the table, so its arguments may not carry as much weight.  Furthermore, it is reported that the kingdom has been shaken by the recent assessment by Standard & Poor that it cannot sustain current government spending levels at this price, so perhaps it will soften its position.  OPEC operates on a principal It operates on the principle of unanimity, and one member, one vote. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OPEC) Members that are pro-quota/pro-change include:  Iran, Venezuela, Algeria, Iraq, Nigeria, Ecuador,  Libya, and Angola. Members that have sufficient reserves or low enough production costs to survive another year of low oil prices include:  Saudi Arabia, UAE, Qatar and Kuwait. Indonesia will join, making 13. The way I count the votes, it looks like there will be some sort of change.  This question asks about a production quota change; if the change OPEC adopts is to establish a price floor, the question will resolve as "no".  Some producers are so desperate for oil revenue (Venezuela, Iran) that I think a production quota will be more appealing to them than a price floor, since they can sell oil like mad up to their quota, but a price floor might cause sales to shift immediately to non-OPEC producers.
Current policy relies on market share rather than production quota's.  It is unlikely that this policy will change since it's implementation has been relatively short.

Per https://www.rt.com/business/236055-us-not-saudi-arabia/ non-OPEC countries accounted for ~56% of oil exports in 2013. Assuming the figures haven't changed too much, it follows that any quotas imposed on OPEC as a collective or individual OPEC countries would have little impact on the price of oil. Any changes drastic enough to have an impact on world oil prices would have a similar (and less tolerable) effect on revenue. However, Indonesia is set to re-join OPEC this December 4 (http://www.cnbc.com/2015/09/08/opec-says-indonesia-to-reactive-its-membership-at-dec-meeting.html). Although it would account for only 3% of OPEC production, the event would provide a reason for a minor adjustment (e.g. to increase the total OPEC quota by median Indonesian production). Conclusion: Most probable event is a small adjustment upwards in total OPEC quota to accommodate Indonesia.

Maintaining forecast at 5%. Per Article 11(c) of the OPEC statute (see below), all OPEC decisions require the unanimous agreement of all its members. I just don't see OPEC as being able to coalesce around a change to the overall quote OR a modification of country specific quotas. Some OPEC states, like Iran, would like to see the overall quota bumped up (to make room for production they have coming online), while other smaller OPEC states have urged a cuts to production to boost oil's market price (and help them fill budget gaps). Given these two contradictory positions, unanimity seems unlikely.  ----------------- Full text of 11(c): "Each Full Member Country shall have one vote. All decisions of the Conference, other than on procedural matters, shall require the unanimous agreement of all Full Members." http://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/OPEC_Statute.pdf. COMMENT:   I have read a lot of pleading and wishful thinking about lowering the quota from countries hurting from low oil prices, but  I have found no arguments  that supporting a reduction in OPEC's quota  would be beneficial in the long term  to OPEC producers--because of loss of market share.    I have thought that perhaps OPEC would lift its quota ceiling to bring it into closer alignment with actual production, or to acknowledge anticipated increased production by Iran, but what would be the point: it  would not reduce supply and/or increase the price of oil.   As for my idea that maybe KSA would want a quota slapped on Iran (so that with the lifting of sanctions its increased  production  doesn't make things worse) I've not read of that either. It's time I join the crowd and go seriously negative.

During the oil glut of the 1980's, the Saudis cut capital spending, kept the dole going, and were very patient.

http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2015/10/17/venezuela-tears-a-page-out-of-opecs-old-playbook-i.aspx?source=iedfolrf0000001 " . . . OPEC members and non-members are expected to come together on Oct. 21 for a technical meeting. At that meeting, it is expected that Venezuela will unveil a strategy from the old playbook used by OPEC and suggest it revert back to its price band strategy to revive the oil price. "What the country is proposing is to set up a series of progressive oil production cuts to control prices.  . . . 
"The band system strategy was first employed by OPEC after oil prices crashed in the late 1990s, when it had a $22 to $28 per barrel band. That strategy worked relatively well until 2005, when demand for oil surged, leading prices to rise past the upper level of the band. The key to that strategy was to keep production in line with demand so that oil wouldn't drop past the $22 per barrel floor. To do so, OPEC, and in some cases non-members, would coordinate a production cut to stabilize the oil price during periods of weaker demand. "We saw this strategy in action in 2001, when OPEC worked with non-members to coordinate a production cut in order to boost oil prices back into the price band of $22 to $28 per barrel. The coordinated cut was announced at an emergency OPEC meeting at the end of December 2001, as OPEC agreed to a 1.5 million barrel per day production cut, which coincided with a combined 462,500 per day production cut by non-OPEC producers Russia, Norway, and Mexico. "The strategy clearly worked, as crude prices quickly rebounded back into the upper end of OPEC's price band. "For such a strategy to work this time around, OPEC will need some level of non-member participation since it has made it abundantly clear that it won't cut alone. The problem lies in the fact that there have been mixed signals from both Russia and Mexico as to their willingness to join a coordinated production cut, while Norway has already said it wouldn't join a cut this time around since its production is no longer as high as it once was because of the declining output from the North Sea. "Mexico is reluctant to cut for the same reason. Its Energy Minister Pedro Joaquin Caldwell told Reuters last month that, "Mexico is not influencing overproduction because Mexico's oil output has been steadily declining," and therefore, "it would be unacceptable for us to have to cut when our output is already declining," saying that a production cut "is not an option." However, Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Zanganeh, who has been working with Venezuela on getting consensus on a production cut, said Mexico "expressed readiness to cooperate with OPEC should OPEC decide to enter market management." So, it's really hard to tell where it stands.  "Likewise, Russia has been sending mixed signals. Its Energy Minister Alexander Novak told reporters earlier this month that it is ready to meet with OPEC and non-OPEC producers to discuss the current oil market situation. However, the country's oil producers said they won't cooperate with OPEC. In fact, one of the country's top oil producers, Rosneft, went so far as to blame OPEC for the continued problems in the oil market. Its CEO Igor Sechin said, "They fail to observe their own quotas [for OPEC oil output]. If quotas had been observed, global oil markets would have been rebalanced by now." In other words, we wouldn't need a coordinated production cut if OPEC wasn't already producing more than its stated quota.   "Venezuela is hoping that by reviving an old strategy it can improve the oil price and, therefore, its economy. However, it still faces a tough sell, as such a move is predicated upon non-OPEC members joining a cut again, as they have in the past. Needless to say, it will take a lot of convincing before that happens since no one is eager to turn off their oil pumps.

The succession of King Salman bin Abdulaziz al-Saud has arguably seen Al-Naimi, the man who twisted arms to get OPEC to not react to low oil prices by cutting production, lose influence within the corridors of power in Riyadh.  Will the current representative of SA to OPEC be as persuasive as Al-Naimi, or even see the situation as he did?

http://news.kuwaittimes.net/website/oil-glut-equity-market-concerns-weigh-on-oil-nbk-economic-report/ As evidenced by this article from the Kuwait Times, the informal word "quota" is used interchangeably with the official, technical term "target." It's all part of the "secret sauce." There should be no doubt whatsoever that the secret formula for the secret sauce is under serious consideration for revision. Whether it is changed or not, I do not know; but that it is under intensive internal OPEC review means that it's "in play." And, once in play, anything can happen. In short, and for my last time on this topic, these (informal yet formal, likely secret, generally disregarded) country-specific "targets" and the overall group (pretend) "ceiling" MATTER, in a bizare, cartelish sort of way; not least of all to the OPEC members themselves and long-term contractual customers and financiers. There's the practical matter of these numbers that is only connected to "strategy" in a "kind of, sort of" way; yet the numbers exist and must be dealt with. Argh. Agent0090!! Much thanks for disabusing me of the notion that the proffered correlation between the total OPEC group quota and that of individual members is no more than a simple summation. It is, in fact, a "secret sauce" clouded by obfuscation (at least for neophytes such as myself). Frankly, the whole thing is a complete semantic nightmare. There are quotas, targets, estimates, etc. Official OPEC communications seem to no longer even reference the word "quota," but instead use the word "ceiling." It seems, then, that there are two sets of variables:
1) An official group "ceiling" of 30 million barrels/day production
2) An official (?) set of "production targets" for 12 of the 13 OPEC members That set #2 variables exist cannot be disputed (see link to Platts website below). Where these country-specific "production targets" come from (who generates them) is unclear. Platts states thay they are set by OPEC. Whether the country-specific "production targets" can be summed into the 30 million b/d ceiling is unknown. On the publicly accessible portion of the Platts website the country specific production targets are only shown month-to-month historically. "OPEC's 30 million b/d ceiling has been in place since January 2012. It does not include individual country quotas."
"OPEC sets a production target for twelve of its 13 members. Iraq ... does not have a production quota."
http://www.platts.com/news-feature/2014/oil/opec-guide/prod_table My guess is that if one worked through the Platts website (a subscription service), a definitive answer to the question of how the country-specific "production targets" correlate to the overall group "ceiling" could be obtained. OPEC is, however, a cartel, and the correlation does not need to make any rational sense. They can, for example, in "magic-like" fashion, simply ignore the logic of mathematical summation, or, not apportion any "production target" to some countries (as with Iraq currently). The point I've been arguing in support of my forecast, however, is that OPEC will try to maintain some semblance of a rational correlation. Else, what is recognized as "magic-like," reveals itself to be mere "magic," and the whole world, including many OPEC producers themselves, simply walk away. Or, in other words, if you accept that the two sets of variables need to be generated under OPEC auspices, what do you think they will be? To my mind, it's a problem for OPEC. No doubt the solution will require a whole slew of fine verbiage and logical gymnastics. Nevertheless, I'm suggesting the solution will also result in some change to the variable set 1. (I've discounted the obvious solution where the variable set 2 is discontinued; because without that, there is no coordination, no OPEC. It's a possibility though. What does not seem like a possibility to me, however, is that OPEC generates a variable 2 set of, say, 40 million b/d, while simultaneously generating a variable 1 set of a 30 million b/d ceiling. The "show" cannot be allowed to become too farcical.) A point previously raised, challenging the technical validity of the question, is apt; although I do believe we all kind of get the intention.

OPEC has maintained and exceeded its production targets to guard its share of the market, amid competition from other global players including US shale oil producers.  As for the powerful Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) it is in a relatively strong financial position, because of Saudi Arabia, as illustrated this summer by its decision to maintain high production for long-term gain even though global oil prices were low. Fuel subsidies and tax reforms will likely be among the first issues tackled by some within the GCC, as early as 2016 if oil prices remain low (i.e., Saudi output is increasingly being directed to its domestic market rather than to foreign consumers). Iran may very well prove to be a model of some of these changes, implementing a fixed cash payment system to help manage society's frustration with shrinking subsidies. Ultimately, the Gulf states are unlikely to try and institute long-term changes to state subsidization schemes soon, especially as they deal with unrest in Syria and Yemen and manage the emerging relationship between the United States and Iran. Looking at the relative reserves and debt load within the GCC, Saudi Arabia with a reserve of ~$800 billion and a debt load of <20% GDP is atypical. Most GCC members have significantly less reserves (~$100 billion) by comparison and carry significant debt load in the range 20-40% of GDP. Bahrain is essential dependent on Saudi financial assistance. Yet, I do not foresee any means by which the GCC, the driving hub of OPEC, could reduce oil production before 1JAN16.  Nor is that there long-term aim at present.

The last (scheduled) OPEC meeting before the January deadline will be held in December. Under normal conditions, this would be a question of supply and demand. Supply far exceeds demand; as it did when the Saudis elected to keep the quota unchanged in 2015. What, if anything, has changed? 
-The US continues to bolster production and pursue alternative energy sources, despite OPEC's driving prices through the floor. 
-In the US, one of OPECS largest/most loyal customers is the US. 2016 is an election year. Reduced dependence on foreign crude will remain a hot-button, as it provides fodder for stump speeches. Americans are particularly responsive to tough talk; and in a field crowded with candidates, with no clear front-runner, the fourth quarter 2015 will be a time for stumping and much podium pounding. A spike in per barrel prices will inflame the drive for US oil production to stay in business, despite profit drains. Therefore, it  is in the interest of all OPEC member countries to keep prices low; i.e, at or near quota.   Meanwhile, all eyes are on Iran. How might an easing or outright lifting of economic sanctions on Iran affect the economic landscape in OPEC countries as a whole? What happens if/when Iran is no longer dependent upon oil revenues for economic survival?

Next OPEC meeting is December 4th in Vienna. That means this question will actually resolve before Jan 1st. Here's my thinking on the matter:
- Some OPEC members will sell below cost because they need cashflow.
- Some OPEC members (and certain non-members, like Russia) are running on old equipment that gives them little control over output.
- At the previous meeting, the Saudis were looking to see how things would shake out vis-a-vis North American shale production; at that time, little evident damage had occurred. We're only at the beginning of the fallout here; although there has been some damage (i.e. corporate failure, or cancellation of projects), some other suppliers have successfully cut costs.
- Certain markets have baked-in selling prices that are higher than Brent or WTI due to politics or supply chain issues; some OPEC members are selling at higher prices than the market looks like as a result.
-There are active conflicts between some of the OPEC members (i.e. Gulf States vs Iran)
- Despite the world being "awash" with oil, there are storage considerations that may limit output.
- There are a number of supply-chain choke-points (Straits of Hormuz is only one example) that can easily get blocked as a result of geopolitical or even weather related issues; this means that the price has the possibility of spiking upwards regardless of current supply. All of the above make this an inherently unpredictable question. I'm currently going in at P=0.75, but will keep a close eye on this one...

20 Aug 2015.  Pressure is building on Saudi Arabia from members within Opec to agree to an emergency meeting to arrest oil prices which are plummeting towards levels of $40 per barrel.  Opec’s next scheduled gathering is due to take place in December but Algeria, Venezuela and a number of other members including Iran are now supporting an earlier meeting to discuss production levels  Algeria has circulated a letter within Opec, lobbying for oil ministers to discuss measures to restore prices. These could include introducing individual production quotas within the group which would prevent certain countries from over-producing. Saudi Arabia’s decision last November to increase its own production, which accounts for around third of the group’s output, to more than 10.6 million barrels per day (bpd) has made it impossible for other members to raise their production.
The country's oil policy has also opened up deep divisions within the group, especially with fellow Middle East power Iran. Riyadh has come under increasing criticism from within Opec for its determination to maintain a policy which has allowed oil prices to go into freefall since last November. Saudi Arabia and its close Gulf allies, such as the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait and Qatar, now account for over 18 million bpd of Opec supply, leaving little room for countries such as Iran, Libya and Iraq to increase their output. “People in Opec are fed up with the Saudi policy of overproducing since November and have lost a lot of revenue because of this.” Tensions within the group have risen further since Iran sealed a historic nuclear deal with world powers, which could lead to potentially more Iranian crude entering an already oversupplied market. Iran's production has been severely curtailed by sanctions and is currently around 2.7 million bpd, but Iran was capable of pumping over 4 million bpd in 2011.  Saudi and its close Gulf allies are unlikely to change their strategy of keeping production at current levels. In doing so they are causing rifts to emerge within Opec. "Individual quotas need to be restored," said the source, who added that Saudi Arabia's aim of pegging back shale oil production in the US had failed. Brent crude tumbled to a new six-year low of $46 per barrel after the US government downgraded its short-term forecast for prices. Opec member revenues fell below $1 trillion last year and that figures is expected to fall further in 2015, with oil prices expected to average around $49 per barrel, according to the Energy Information Administration. Opec and officials in Saudia Arabia did not respond to requests for comment.
